item.title: Continuity
item.description: Continuous functions can be drawn without picking up your pencil…? The \(\varepsilon\)-\(\delta\), limit related definition A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is continuous at a point \(c \in \mathcal{D}\) if and only if the limit of \(f\) at \(c\) exists and \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)\). That is, for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(\vert x - c \vert < \delta\) implies \(\vert f(x) - f(c) \vert < \varepsilon\).

item.title: Functions
item.description: Also called maps. Definitions A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C}\) is a set of ordered pairs \((a,b)\) where \(a \in \mathcal{D}\) and \(b \in \mathcal{C}\) with the property that if \((a,b) \in f\) and \((a,c) \in f\), then \(b=c\). If \((a,b) \in f\), we write \(f(a)=b\). We call the set \(\mathcal{D}\) the domain of \(f\) and the set \(\mathcal{C}\) the codomain of \(f\). We call the set \(\{f(x) \mid x \in \mathcal{D}\}\) the image of \(f\), denoted \(\im f\).

item.title: Sequences
item.description: They’re like lists but they’re infinitely long. Definitions For real numbers, a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}\), where the image of the number \(n\) under \(f\) is typically called \(a_n\). The sequence is written by listing its images: \(a_1, a_2, \dots\) or for short, \(\{a_n\}\). In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to X\), where the image of the number \(i\) under \(f\) is typically called \(x_i\).

item.title: Infimum and supremum
item.description: Definitions Let \(A \subset \mathbb{R}\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is an upper bound of \(A\) if and only if \(c \geq a\) for all \(a \in A\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is a lower bound of \(A\) if and only if \(c \leq a\) for all \(a \in A\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is the greatest/largest/maximum element of \(A\) if and only if \(c\) is an upper bound of \(A\) and \(c \in A\).

item.title: Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)
item.description: Theorem statement Let \(f: [a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be continuous and let \(L \in \mathbb{R}\) be a number strictly between \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\). Then there exists a \(c \in (a,b)\) such that \(f(c) = L\). Lemma Let \(a, L \in \mathbb{R}\) and let \(f\) be a function that is continuous at \(a\) with \(f(a) < L\) (\(f(a) > L\)). Then there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(\vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies that \(f(x) < L\) (\(f(x) > L\)).

item.title: Real number exponents
item.description: If \(a>0\) and \(r\) are real numbers, does \(a^r\) make sense? We need to extend exponentiation beyond repeated multiplication… \(n\)th roots Let \(n \in \N\) be a natural number and let \(a > 0\). Then we define the \(n\)th root of \(a\), written \(a^{\frac{1}{n}}\) or \(\sqrt[n]{a}\) to be the unique positive real number whose \(n\)th power is \(a\). Proposition: Such a number \(\sqrt[n]{a}\) exists for all \(a>0\) and \(n \in \N\).

item.title: The boundedness theorem
item.description: Theorem statement If \(f: [a,b] \to \R\) is a continuous function, then \(f\) is bounded. Lemmata Lemma 1: If \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \R\) is continuous at \(a \in \mathcal{D}\), then there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(f\) is bounded on \((a - \delta, a + \delta)\). Proof 1: Let \(\varepsilon = 1\). By the continuity of \(f\) at \(a\), choose \(\delta > 0\) such that \(\vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies \(\vert f(x) - f(a) \vert < \varepsilon = 1\).

item.title: The Extreme Value Theorem (EVT)
item.description: Theorem statement If \(f: [a,b] \to \R\) be a continuous function, then there exist \(c,d \in [a,b]\) such that \(f(c) \leq f(x) \leq f(d)\) for all \(x \in [a,b]\). Proof Suppose \(f: [a,b] \to \R\) be a continuous function. Then by the boundedness theorem, the set \(A = \{f(x) \mid x \in [a,b]\}\) is bounded and nonempty. By the completeness axiom, the set \(A\) has a supremum, say \(\sup A = M\).

item.title: Limits
item.description: Intuitively, “\(\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L\)” means that the outputs of a function \(f\) approaches the value \(L\) as the inputs approach the value \(a\). The \(\varepsilon\)-\(\delta\) definition of a limit (and variants) Let \(f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a function and let \(a,L \in \mathbb{R}\). \(\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L\) if and only if for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(0 < \vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies that \(\vert f(x) - L \vert < \varepsilon\).

item.title: Discontinuities
item.description: Definition A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is discontinuous at a point \(c \in \mathcal{D}\) if and only if \(f\) is not continuous at \(c\). That is, if the limit \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x)\) does not exist or is not equal to \(f(c)\). Types of discontinuities Let \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a function and \(c \in \mathcal{D}\). Then \(f\) has an infinite discontinuity at \(c\) if and only if \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = \pm \infty\).
